thread.title: Lady Eagles move forward into quarterfinals
thread.title_full: Lady Eagles move forward into quarterfinals

author: Michael Foster Forsyth County News (noreply@cherokeetribune.com)
title: Lady Eagles move forward into quarterfinals
text: Lady Eagles move forward into quarterfinals by Michael FosterForsyth County News Cherokee Tribune October 21, 2015 01:06 AM | 575 views | 0 | 4 | | Paige Horton had 14 kills Tuesday as Etowah swept past Lambert to reach the quarterfinal round of the Class state playoffs. Staff file photo slideshow SUWANEE — Senior outside hitters Natalie Lucco and Paige Horton were the difference for Etowah’s volleyball team Tuesday night, logging 14 kills apiece in a 3-0 sweep of Lambert in the second round of the Class state playoffs.Etowah (39-10) won a decisive first set 25-14 before Lambert (35-11) took a deep breath, recalibrated and battled with the Lady Eagles through a 25-19 second set and into the third. In the third set, Lambert held a 22-20 advantage, but Lucco and middle hitter Nicole Ferris helped Etowah battle back, eventually winning the match with a 26-24 decision.Lambert coach Missy Hall felt like her team failed to play to its strengths until it was too late, but it still got production from a healthier Ashley Cruise, who registered seven kills after playing recent matches with a tender Achilles, and eight kills from Sarah Thierer.While the season ended, Hall has a unique situation on her hand — her team will return the entire lot next season. She has no seniors on the roster.“We’re young,” Hall said. “They exceeded expectations this season. It’s a good thing for them. They’ve been here now, but this should have stung, and when we come back in August, this will stick in the back of their head. Hopefully, it motivates them.”For Etowah coach Kim Robertson, Tuesday’s victory sent her team to the state quarterfinals for the second time in her eight-year tenure at the school. The Lady Eagles were learn their next opponent today, after the Georgia High School Association reseeds the final eight teams.“I have a bunch of seniors and girls that have played together for a long time, and their mentality is to win a state championship,” Robertson said. “It’s important for them. A lot of them have played for years in club ball and high school ball. I think this was one of the best matches we played this season.”Etowah jumped out to a 16-7 lead in the first set, thanks to six kills and a block from Horton. After Lambert was seemingly overwhelmed by the firepower on the edges, Hall rallied her team going into the second set.An emotional lift prompted Lambert to come back from a 6-1 deficit in the second set and keep things close at 13-13 and 16-16 at consecutive timeouts, but consecutive aces from Jessie Cohen helped Etowah pull away.In the third set, Lambert was on par, taking an 11-7 lead into the first timeout and eventually leading by two later on, but it was “too little, too late.”“Historically, we are a slow-starting team. When we get on the big stage, sometimes we disappear a little bit, and our big players did not show what they are capable (Tuesday), unfortunately,” Hall said. “Our strengths are serving, blocking and hitting, but our hitters had a rough night. Give credit to Etowah because they scouted perfectly.”
